content.text:
# 2024 Utah Republican presidential caucuses

Trump
Haley
| image1 = Official Presidential Portrait of President Donald J. Trump (2025).jpg
| candidate1 = Donald Trump
| color1 = 283681
| home_state1 = Florida
| popular_vote1 = 48,350
| percentage1 = 56.35%
| delegate_count1 = 40
| image2 = Nikki Haley (53299447738) (cropped).jpg
| candidate2 = Nikki Haley
| color2 = FE6100
| home_state2 = South Carolina
| popular_vote2 = 36,621
| percentage2 = 42.68%
| delegate_count2 = 0
| flag_image = Flag of Utah (2011–2024).svg
}}
The 2024 Utah Republican presidential caucuses were held on March 5, 2024, as part of the Republican Party primaries for the 2024 presidential election. 40 delegates to the 2024 Republican National Convention were allocated on a winner-take-most basis. The contest was held on Super Tuesday alongside primaries in 14 other states. Donald Trump won most of the counties along with all 40 delegates, but Nikki Haley won Salt Lake and Davis counties.
Controversy
Technological and staffing issues led to Utah being the last state to report Super Tuesday results. Voters faced difficulties in casting their vote and some gave up on the process.
Endorsements
State senators
* Evan Vickers, District 28 (2013–present); Majority Leader (2019–present) (switched endorsement to Haley)
* Scott Sandall, District 1 (2023–present) and District 17 (2019–2023)
* Todd Weiler, District 8 (2023–present) and District 23 (2012–2023)
* Lincoln Fillmore, District 17 (2023–present) and District 10 (2016–2023)
* Daniel McCay, District 18 (2023–present) and District 11 (2019–2023)
* Kirk Cullimore Jr., District 19 (2023–present) and District 9 (2019–2023)
* Jake Anderegg, District 22 (2023–present) and District 13 (2017–2023)
* Curt Bramble, District 24 (2023–present) and District 16 (2001–2023)
* Mike McKell, District 25 (2023–present) and District 7 (2021–2023) (switched endorsement to Haley)
* Derrin Owens, District 27 (2023–present) and District 24 (2021–2023)
State representatives
* Mike Schultz, District 12 (2015–present); Majority Leader (2021–present)
* Jefferson Moss, District 51 (2023–present) and District 2 (2017–2023); Majority Whip (2021–present)
* Dan Johnson, District 3 (2023–present) and District 4 (2019–2023)
* Kera Birkeland, District 4 (2023–present) and District 53 (2020–2023)
* Casey Snider, District 5 (2019–present)
* Ryan Wilcox, District 7 (2009–2014 and 2021–present)
* Karen M. Peterson, District 13 (2022–present)
* Karianne Lisonbee, District 14 (2017–present)
* Paul Cutler, District 18 (2023–present)
* Timothy Hawkes, District 18 (2015–2022)
* Raymond Ward, District 19 (2015–present)
* Melissa Garff Ballard, District 20 (2019–present)
* Ken Ivory, District 39 (2023–present) and District 47 (2011–2019 and 2021–2023)
* Robert Spendlove, District 42 (2023–present) and District 49 (2014–2023)
* Jordan Teuscher, District 44 (2023–present) and District 42 (2021–2023)
* Susan Pulsipher, District 45 (2023–present) and District 50 (2017–2023)
* Candice Pierucci, District 49 (2023–present) and District 52 (2019–2023)
* Kay Christofferson, District 53 (2023–present) and District 56 (2013–2023)
* Brady Brammer, District 54 (2023–present) and District 27 (2019–2023)
* Jon Hawkins, District 55 (2023–present) and District 57 (2019–2023)
* Jefferson Burton, District 64 (2023–present) and District 66 (2021–2023)
* Doug Welton, District 65 (2023–present) and District 67 (2021–2023)
* Christine Watkins, District 67 (2023–present) and District 69 (2009–2012 and 2017–2023)
* Walt Brooks, District 75 (2016–present)
County official
* Aimee Winder Newton, Salt Lake County Councilwoman from District 3 (2014–present)
}}
(2003-2021)
State executive officials
*Deidre Henderson, Lieutenant Governor of Utah (2021-present); Utah State Senator from District 7 (2013-2021)
State senators
*Evan Vickers, Majority Leader of the Utah Senate (2019-present) from the 28th district (2013-present) (switched support from Ron DeSantis)
* Mike McKell, District 25 (2023–present) and District 7 (2021–2023); Utah State Representative from District 25 (2013–2021) (switched support from Ron DeSantis)
*Ann Millner, District 5 (2023-present) and District 18 (2015-2023)
State representatives
*Casey Snider, District 5 (2019-present)
Notable Individuals
*Abby Cox, First Lady of Utah (2021-present)
}}
U.S. Representative
* Burgess Owens, UT-04 (2021–present)
State Representative
* Phil Lyman, Member of the Utah House of Representatives from the 69th district (2023–present) and the 73rd district (2019–2023)
Local official
*Trent Staggs, Mayor of Riverton (2018–present); Riverton City Councilman from District 4 (2014–2018); Republican candidate for U.S. Senator from Utah in 2024 (previously endorsed Ron DeSantis)
}}

.]]
